How to use this package

Mauricio Vargas S.

2020-04-02

Source: vignettes/basic-usage.Rmd
basic-usage.Rmd

Package data

Available tables

Provided that this package obtains data from an API, it is useful to know which tables can be accessed:

library(tradestatistics)

ots_tables
#>                  table
#>  1:          countries
#>  2:           products
#>  3:          reporters
#>  4:           sections
#>  5: product_shortnames
#>  6:   country_rankings
#>  7:   product_rankings
#>  8:               yrpc
#>  9:                yrp
#> 10:                yrc
#> 11:                 yr
#> 12:           yr-short
#> 13:              yr-ga
#> 14:              yr-sa
#> 15:                 yc
#>                                                                                    description
#>  1:                                                                         Countries metadata
#>  2:                                                                           Product metadata
#>  3:                                                                        Reporting countries
#>  4:                                                                           Product sections
#>  5:                                                                        Product short names
#>  6:                                                                       Ranking of countries
#>  7:                                                                        Ranking of products
#>  8:         Reporter-Partner trade at product level (Year, Reporter, Partner and Product Code)
#>  9:                    Reporter-Partner trade at aggregated level (Year, Reporter and Partner)
#> 10:                          Reporter trade at product level (Year, Reporter and Product Code)
#> 11: Reporter trade at aggregated level (Year and Reporter, with top exported/imported Product)
#> 12:                           Reporter trade at aggregated level (Year and Reporter, Abridged)
#> 13:   Reporter trade at aggregated level (Year and Reporter, with top exported/imported Group)
#> 14: Reporter trade at aggregated level (Year and Reporter, with top exported/imported Section)
#> 15:                                    Product trade at detailed level (Year and Product Code)
#>                                                                              source
#>  1:                                                UN Comtrade (with modifications)
#>  2:                                                UN Comtrade (with modifications)
#>  3:                                                UN Comtrade (with modifications)
#>  4: Center for International Development at Harvard University (with modifications)
#>  5:                     The Observatory of Economic Complexity (with modifications)
#>  6:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#>  7:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#>  8:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#>  9:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#> 10:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#> 11:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#> 12:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#> 13:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#> 14:                                                           Open Trade Statistics
#> 15:                                                           Open Trade Statistics

You might notice the tables have a pattern. The letters indicate the presence of columns that account for the level of detail in the data:

  • y: year column.
  • r: reporter column
  • p: partner column
  • c: product code column

The most aggregated table is yr which basically says how many dollars each country exports and imports for a given year.

The less aggregated table is yrpc which says how many dollars of each of the 1,222 products from the Harmonized System each country exports to other countries and imports from other countries.

For the complete detail you can check docs.tradestatistics.io.

Country codes

The Package Functions section explains that you don’t need to memorize all ISO codes. The functions within this package are designed to match strings (i.e. “United States” or “America”) to valid ISO codes (i.e. “USA”).

Just as a reference, the table with all valid ISO codes can be accessed by running this:

ots_countries
#>      country_iso                          country_name_english
#>   1:         afg                                   Afghanistan
#>   2:         alb                                       Albania
#>   3:         dza                                       Algeria
#>   4:         asm                                American Samoa
#>   5:         and                                       Andorra
#>  ---                                                          
#> 245:        c-am Alias for all valid ISO codes in the Americas
#> 246:        c-as         Alias for all valid ISO codes in Asia
#> 247:        c-eu       Alias for all valid ISO codes in Europe
#> 248:        c-oc      Alias for all valid ISO codes in Oceania
#> 249:         all    Alias for all valid ISO codes in the World
#>      country_fullname_english continent_id continent eu28_member
#>   1:              Afghanistan            1      Asia           0
#>   2:                  Albania            2    Europe           0
#>   3:                  Algeria            3    Africa           0
#>   4:           American Samoa            4   Oceania           0
#>   5:                  Andorra            2    Europe           0
#>  ---                                                            
#> 245:                     <NA>           NA      <NA>          NA
#> 246:                     <NA>           NA      <NA>          NA
#> 247:                     <NA>           NA      <NA>          NA
#> 248:                     <NA>           NA      <NA>          NA
#> 249:                     <NA>           NA      <NA>          NA

Product codes and communities

The Package Functions section explains that you don’t need to memorize all HS codes. The functions within this package are designed to match strings (i.e. “apple”) to valid HS codes (i.e. “0808”).

ots_products
#>       product_code
#>    1:         0101
#>    2:         0102
#>    3:         0103
#>    4:         0104
#>    5:         0105
#>   ---             
#> 1316:           95
#> 1317:           96
#> 1318:           97
#> 1319:           99
#> 1320:          all
#>                                                                                product_fullname_english
#>    1:                                                            Horses, asses, mules and hinnies; live
#>    2:                                                                              Bovine animals; live
#>    3:                                                                                       Swine; live
#>    4:                                                                             Sheep and goats; live
#>    5:     Poultry; live, fowls of the species Gallus domesticus, ducks, geese, turkeys and guinea fowls
#>   ---                                                                                                  
#> 1316: Alias for all codes in the group Toys, games and sports requisites; parts and accessories thereof
#> 1317:                              Alias for all codes in the group Miscellaneous manufactured articles
#> 1318:                    Alias for all codes in the group Works of art; collectors' pieces and antiques
#> 1319:                      Alias for all codes in the group Commodities not specified according to kind
#> 1320:                                                                               Alias for all codes

ots_products_shortnames
#>       product_code product_shortname_english
#>    1:         0101                    Horses
#>    2:         0102                    Bovine
#>    3:         0103                      Pigs
#>    4:         0104           Sheep and Goats
#>    5:         0105                   Poultry
#>   ---                                       
#> 1218:         9703                Sculptures
#> 1219:         9704            Revenue Stamps
#> 1220:         9705         Collector's Items
#> 1221:         9706                  Antiques
#> 1222:         9999               Unspecified
ots_sections
#>       product_code section_code
#>    1:         0101           01
#>    2:         0102           01
#>    3:         0103           01
#>    4:         0104           01
#>    5:         0105           01
#>   ---                          
#> 1218:         9703           21
#> 1219:         9704           21
#> 1220:         9705           21
#> 1221:         9706           21
#> 1222:         9999           22

ots_sections_shortnames
#>     section_code        section_shortname_english
#>  1:           01                  Animal Products

#>  9:           09                    Wood Products
#> 10:           10                      Paper Goods
#> 11:           11                         Textiles
#> 12:           12            Footwear and Headwear

#> 15:           15                           Metals
#> 16:           16                         Machines
#> 17:           17                   Transportation
#> 18:           18                      Instruments
#> 19:           19                          Weapons
#> 20:           20                    Miscellaneous
#> 21:           21                Arts and Antiques

#>     section_code        section_shortname_english

Package functions

Country code

The end user can use this function to find an ISO code by providing a country name. This works by implementing partial search.

Basic examples:

# Single match with no replacement
ots_country_code("Chile")
#>    country_iso country_name_english country_fullname_english continent_id
#> 1:         chl                Chile                    Chile            5
#>    continent eu28_member
#> 1:  Americas           0

# Single match with replacement
ots_country_code("America")
#>    country_iso country_name_english
#> 1:         usa                  USA
#>                                                       country_fullname_english
#> 1: USA, Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands (excludes Virgin Islands until 1981)
#>    continent_id continent eu28_member
#> 1:            5  Americas           0

# Double match with no replacement
ots_country_code("Germany")
#>    country_iso     country_name_english
#> 1:         ddr Fmr Dem. Rep. of Germany
#> 2:         deu                  Germany
#>                                   country_fullname_english continent_id
#> 1:                                Fmr Dem. Rep. of Germany            2
#> 2: Germany (former Federal Republic of Germany until 1990)            2
#>    continent eu28_member
#> 1:    Europe           0
#> 2:    Europe           1

The function ots_country_code() is used by ots_create_tidy_data() in a way that you can pass parameters like ots_create_tidy_data(... reporters = "Chile" ...) and it will automatically replace your input for a valid ISO in case there is a match. This will be covered in detail in the Trade Data section.

Product code

The end user can use this function to find a product code by providing a product name. This works by implementing partial string matching:

ots_product_code(" WiNe ")
#>     product_code
#>  1:         0103
#>  2:         0203
#>  3:         0206
#>  4:         2204
#>  5:         2205
#>  6:         2307
#>  7:         5607
#>  8:         5608
#>  9:         5609
#> 10:         6310
#> 11:         8435
#> 12:           56
#>                                                                                                                                 product_fullname_english
#>  1:                                                                                                                                          Swine; live
#>  2:                                                                                                              Meat of swine; fresh, chilled or frozen
#>  3:                                       Edible offal of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats, horses, asses, mules or hinnies; fresh, chilled or frozen
#>  4:                                                      Wine of fresh grapes, including fortified wines; grape must other than that of heading no. 2009
#>  5:                                                                Vermouth and other wine of fresh grapes, flavoured with plants or aromatic substances
#>  6:                                                                                                                                     Wine lees; argol
#>  7: Twine, cordage, ropes and cables, whether or not plaited or braided; whether or not impregnated, coated, covered or sheathed with rubber or plastics
#>  8:                                           Twine, cordage or rope; knotted netting, made up fishing nets and other made up nets, of textile materials
#>  9:                                   Articles of yarn, strip or the like of heading no. 5404 or 5405; twine, cordage, rope or cables n.e.c. or included
#> 10:               Rags; used or new, scrap twine, cordage, rope and cables and worn out articles of twine, cordage, rope or cables, of textile materials
#> 11:                                   Presses, crushers and similar machinery; used in the manufacture of wine, cider, fruit juices or similar beverages
#> 12:                   Alias for all codes in the group Wadding, felt and nonwovens, special yarns; twine, cordage, ropes and cables and articles thereof
#>     type_product
#>  1:         WiNe
#>  2:         WiNe
#>  3:         WiNe
#>  4:         WiNe
#>  5:         WiNe
#>  6:         WiNe
#>  7:         WiNe
#>  8:         WiNe
#>  9:         WiNe
#> 10:         WiNe
#> 11:         WiNe
#> 12:         WiNe

This function searches both products and groups:

ots_product_code(productname = " ShEEp ", productgroup = " mEaT ")
#>    group_code     group_fullname_english product_code
#> 1:         02 Meat and edible meat offal         0204
#> 2:         02 Meat and edible meat offal         0206
#>                                                                                          product_fullname_english
#> 1:                                                               Meat of sheep or goats; fresh, chilled or frozen
#> 2: Edible offal of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats, horses, asses, mules or hinnies; fresh, chilled or frozen
#>    type_name type_group
#> 1:     ShEEp       mEaT
#> 2:     ShEEp       mEaT

Section code

The end user can use this function to find a community code by providing a community name. This works by implementing partial string matching:

ots_product_section(" tExTiLeS ")
#>      section_code      section_fullname_english product_code type_section
#>   1:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         5111     tExTiLeS
#>   2:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         5001     tExTiLeS
#>   3:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         5002     tExTiLeS
#>   4:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         5003     tExTiLeS
#>   5:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         5004     tExTiLeS
#>  ---                                                                     
#> 148:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         6306     tExTiLeS
#> 149:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         6307     tExTiLeS
#> 150:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         6308     tExTiLeS
#> 151:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         6309     tExTiLeS
#> 152:           11 Textiles And Textile Articles         6310     tExTiLeS

Trade data

This function downloads data for a single year and needs (at least) some filter parameters according to the query type.

Here we cover aggregated tables to describe the usage.

Bilateral trade at product level (Year - Reporter - Partner - Product Code)

If we want Chile-Argentina bilateral trade at community level in 1962:

ots_create_tidy_data(
  years = 1962,
  reporters = "chl",
  partners = "arg",
  table = "yrpc"
)
#>      year reporter_iso reporter_fullname_english partner_iso
#>   1: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#>   2: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#>   3: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#>   4: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#>   5: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#>  ---                                                        
#> 262: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#> 263: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#> 264: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#> 265: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#> 266: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#>      partner_fullname_english section_code section_color
#>   1:                Argentina           21       #7485aa
#>   2:                Argentina           20       #4d6fd0
#>   3:                Argentina           20       #4d6fd0
#>   4:                Argentina           20       #4d6fd0
#>   5:                Argentina           20       #4d6fd0
#>  ---                                                    
#> 262:                Argentina           02       #406662
#> 263:                Argentina           02       #406662
#> 264:                Argentina           02       #406662
#> 265:                Argentina           02       #406662
#> 266:                Argentina           02       #406662
#>      section_shortname_english                      section_fullname_english

#>   2:             Miscellaneous           Miscellaneous Manufactured Articles
#>   3:             Miscellaneous           Miscellaneous Manufactured Articles

#>   1:         97
#>   2:         96

We can pass two years or more, several reporters/partners, and filter by community with exact codes or code matching based on keywords:

# Note that here I'm passing Peru and not per which is the ISO code for Peru
# The same applies to Brazil
ots_create_tidy_data(
  years = c(1962,1963),
  reporters = c("chl", "Peru", "bol"),
  partners = c("arg", "Brazil"),
  sections = c("01", "food"),
  table = "yrpc"
)
#> Warning in ots_create_tidy_data_unmemoised(...): The sections argument will be
#> ignored provided that you requested a table without section_code field.
#>       year reporter_iso reporter_fullname_english partner_iso

#>    2: 1962          bol                   Bolivia         arg
#>    3: 1962          bol                   Bolivia         arg
#>    4: 1962          bol                   Bolivia         arg
#>    5: 1962          bol                   Bolivia         arg
#>   ---                                                        
#> 2271: 1963          per                      Peru         bra
#> 2272: 1963          per                      Peru         bra
#> 2273: 1963          per                      Peru         bra
#> 2274: 1963          per                      Peru         bra
#> 2275: 1963          per                      Peru         bra

#> 2272:         2610                  Chromium Ore
#> 2273:         2605                    Cobalt Ore
#> 2274:         2301       Animal Meal and Pellets
#> 2275:         1604                Processed Fish
#>                                                                                                                                                                               product_fullname_english
#>    1:           Fishing rods, fish-hooks and other line fishing tackle; fish landing nets and the like; decoy birds (not those of heading no. 9208 or 9705) and similar hunting or shooting requisites
#>    2:                                               Gymnastics, athletics, other sports (including table tennis) or outdoor games equipment, n.e.c. in this chapter, swimming pools and paddling pools
#>    3:                                          Games; funfair, table or parlour, articles thereof including pintables billiards, special tables for casino games and automatic bowling alley equipment
#>    4: Tricycles, scooters, pedal cars and similar wheeled toys; dolls' carriages; dolls; other toys; reduced-size (scale) models and similar recreational models, working or not; puzzles of all kinds
#>    5:                                                                                                                                                Furniture and parts thereof, n.e.c. in chapter 94
#>   ---                                                                                                                                                                                                 
#> 2271:                                                                                                                                                                   Tungsten ores and concentrates
#> 2272:                                                                                                                                                                   Chromium ores and concentrates
#> 2273:                                                                                                                                                                     Cobalt ores and concentrates
#> 2274:                                        Flours, meal and pellets, of meat or meat offal, of fish or of crustaceans, molluscs or other aquatic invertebrates, unfit for human consumption; greaves
#> 2275:                                                                                                                Prepared or preserved fish; caviar and caviar substitutes prepared from fish eggs
#>       export_value_usd import_value_usd
#>    1:               NA             2037
#>    2:               NA             2037
#>    3:               NA             2000
#>    4:               NA             2000
#>    5:               NA            41300
#>   ---                                  
#> 2271:            10000               NA
#> 2272:            31481               NA
#> 2273:            21481               NA
#> 2274:           263519               NA
#> 2275:             7314             2500

yrpc table returns some fields that deserve an explanation which can be seen at docs.tradestatistics.io.

Bilateral trade at aggregated level (Year - Reporter - Partner)

If we want Chile-Argentina bilateral trade at aggregated level in 1962 and 1963:

ots_create_tidy_data(
  years = 1962:1963,
  reporters = c("chl", "per"),
  partners = "arg",
  table = "yrp"
)
#>    year reporter_iso reporter_fullname_english partner_iso
#> 1: 1962          chl                     Chile         arg
#> 2: 1963          chl                     Chile         arg
#> 3: 1962          per                      Peru         arg
#> 4: 1963          per                      Peru         arg
#>    partner_fullname_english export_value_usd import_value_usd
#> 1:                Argentina         23123604         45084101
#> 2:                Argentina         25652535         60132423
#> 3:                Argentina         10643505         29279446
#> 4:                Argentina          8926998         46246476

This table accepts different years, reporters and partners just like yrpc.

Reporter trade at product level (Year - Reporter - Product Code)

If we want Chilean trade at product level in 1962 with respect to product 0101 which means “Horses, asses, mules and hinnies; live”:

ots_create_tidy_data(
  years = 1962,
  reporters = "chl",
  products = "0101",
  table = "yrc"
)
#>    year reporter_iso reporter_fullname_english section_code section_color
#> 1: 1962          chl                     Chile           01       #74c0e2
#>    section_shortname_english      section_fullname_english group_code
#> 1:           Animal Products Live Animals; Animal Products         01
#>    group_fullname_english product_code product_shortname_english
#> 1:          Animals; live         0101                    Horses
#>                  product_fullname_english export_value_usd export_rca
#> 1: Horses, asses, mules and hinnies; live           289076     0.5339
#>    import_value_usd import_rca
#> 1:            50833     0.0927

This table accepts different years, reporters and product codes just like yrpc.

All the variables from this table are documented at docs.tradestatistics.io.

Reporter trade at aggregated level (Year - Reporter)

If we want the aggregated trade of Chile, Argentina and Peru in 1962 and 1963:

yr <- ots_create_tidy_data(
  years = 1962:1963,
  reporters = c("chl", "arg", "per"),
  table = "yr"
)

yr
#>    year reporter_iso reporter_fullname_english export_value_usd
#> 1: 1962          arg                 Argentina       1497724584
#> 2: 1963          arg                 Argentina       1689338136
#> 3: 1962          chl                     Chile        686689403
#> 4: 1963          chl                     Chile        684739946
#> 5: 1962          per                      Peru        676343986
#> 6: 1963          per                      Peru        785459639
#>    import_value_usd top_export_product_code top_import_product_code
#> 1:       1789906161                    1001                    8456
#> 2:       1283218008                    0201                    8456
#> 3:        695823377                    7403                    8456
#> 4:        771099193                    7402                    8456
#> 5:        601437849                    2301                    8703
#> 6:        651334910                    2301                    8703
#>    top_export_trade_value_usd top_import_trade_value_usd cci_fitness_method

#> 2:                  227590947                  105553319             0.0201

#> 5:                -0.2777                          55

This table accepts different years and reporters just like yrpc.

All the variables from this table are documented at docs.tradestatistics.io.

Product trade at aggregated level (Year - Product Code)

If we want all products traded in 1962:

ots_create_tidy_data(
  years = 1962,
  table = "yc"
)

If we want the traded values of the product 0101 which means "Horses, asses, mules and hinnies; live: in 1962:

ots_create_tidy_data(
  years = 1962,
  products = "0101",
  table = "yc"
)
#>    year section_code section_color section_shortname_english
#> 1: 1962           01       #74c0e2           Animal Products
#>         section_fullname_english group_code group_fullname_english product_code
#> 1: Live Animals; Animal Products         01          Animals; live         0101
#>    product_shortname_english               product_fullname_english
#> 1:                    Horses Horses, asses, mules and hinnies; live
#>    export_value_usd import_value_usd top_exporter_iso
#> 1:        100026327        100026327              gbr
#>    top_exporter_fullname_english top_exporter_trade_value_usd top_importer_iso
#> 1:                United Kingdom                     21472229              fra
#>    top_importer_fullname_english top_importer_trade_value_usd
#> 1:      France (includes Monaco)                     25004734
#>    pci_fitness_method pci_rank_fitness_method pci_reflections_method
#> 1:              0.003                     560                -0.6957
#>    pci_rank_reflections_method pci_eigenvalues_method
#> 1:                         759                -0.6955
#>    pci_rank_eigenvalues_method
#> 1:                         759

This table accepts different years just like yrpc.

Inflation adjustment

Taking the yr table from above, we can use ots_inflation_adjustment() to convert dollars from 1962 to dollars of 1970:

ots_inflation_adjustment(yr, reference_year = 1970)
